awd_titl_txt: CCF-BSF: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Practice-Friendly Theory and Algorithms for Linear Regression Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
The project focuses on one of the most fundamental problems in the intersection of applied mathematics and computer science: solving systems of multiple linear equations in multiple variables. Such systems, also known as linear regression problems, have applications in various fields, from classical engineering to data science and machine learning. These applications yield systems with millions of equations and variables. The design of very efficient solver algorithms is thus a problem of paramount importance. Over the last twenty years there has been a tremendous focus and progress in the theory of algorithms for solving certain types of linear systems that are ubiquitous in applications, despite the fact that they are somewhat restricted (e.g. each equation has only two variables). Along with these algorithms, a wealth of new notions, techniques and tools has been acquired. The project will develop extensions of these techniques, targeting concrete applications in related fields. Towards this end, the project includes research problems that are appropriate for advanced undergraduate and graduate students with complementary interests and skills, ranging from applied to theoretical. Research will be disseminated through all standard channels, importantly including free software.

The project will pursue three main directions: (i) Bring the recent progress from the theoretical to the practical realm. Linear system solvers are useful in a variety of contexts, implying a need for implementations in disparate computational environments, including basic consumer computers, graphical processing units, or big parallel and distributed systems. This necessitates the development of new theory and algorithms that are practice-friendly, i.e. designed with the practical performance end-goal in mind. (ii) The impact of linear system solvers in the downstream applications in Data Science and Machine Learning can be accelerated and strengthened by pursuing their tighter integration with the target applications. A second major goal of the project is thus to pursue an exportation of techniques and notions from the theory of linear regression to specific problems in Machine Learning. This will require the development of adaptations and enhancements of these techniques. (iii) The study of specific algorithmic applications in Machine Learning also serves the third major goal of the project: the design of solvers for regression problems that go beyond the restricted types for which efficient solvers are currently known.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit:
The project supported the following major efforts:

(i) The development of theory and related algorithms on improving the performance of classical spectral clustering algorithms. The related work "Spectral Modification of Graphs for Improved Spectral Clustering" appeared in NeurIPS 2019. 

(ii) The development of practice-friendly software for the solution of linear systems of equations in non-proprietary languages (Julia). The software has been made publicly available here: GitHub - bodhi91/CombinatorialMultigrid.jl: Implements the Combinatorial Multigrid 

(iii) The design of numerical, regression-based partitioning algorithms for hypergraphs, that also rely on highly non-trivial data structures and other combinatorial algorithms of independent interest.

These algorithms were implemented and made publicly available here: GitHub - TILOS-AI-Institute/HypergraphPartitioning: Hypergraph Partitioning: benchmarks, evaluators, best known solutions and codes

The work on hypergraph partitioning introduced a new paradigm of supervised spectral algorithms that use the output of existing heuristic algorithms as 'hints' for computing better solutions. The new algorithms led to significantly improved results on multiple benchmarks. 

The associated paper "SpecPart: A supervised spectral framework for Hypergraph Partitioning Solution Improvement"  received the William J. McCalla ICCAD Best Paper Award at the 41st ACM/IEEE ICCAD. 

The project has also supported other research efforts and publications by the PI and students. These include papers that were in submission at the time of the completion of this project, and the following published works, spanning theory and applications:

  • " A generalized Cheeger Inequality" (Linear Algebra and Applications, 2022)
  • "Spectral hypergraph partitioning revisited", (ACDA 2021)
  • "A novel calibration step in gene network construction" (Frontiers, Bioinformatics, 2021)


Broader Impacts

Education: The project enabled the PI to build a group of students at NJIT, where the research work was performed. The project partially supported four PhD students, including two female students. One has graduated and is now employed as a University Lecturer, while the second is expected to graduate in 2023. The PI also advised remotely one MS student from Iowa State, who is now a PhD student at UCSD. 

The project's second and third years were performed under the constraints of the 2020 pandemic. During this time the PI developed new course materials, and he was assigned the design of two online courses (Machine Learning and Deep Learning) that have become NJIT's official online course offerings for its virtual campus program. In addition, in late 2022, as an Associate Chair for Graduate Studies, the PI led efforts to design his College's plan for Broadening Participation in Computing.  

Impact on Semiconductor Industry: The work on hypergraph partitioning was motivated by key problems in FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Arrays) design and it was done in collaboration with research groups in the semiconductor industry (Xilinx, AMD), who co-authored the related work. The collaborative work contributed to the knowledge transfer of practice-friendly algorithms, one of the project's original goals. This opened the way for the industrial adoption of numerical regression algorithms that can potentially complement and eventually replace the currently used decades-old algorithms.
